overview_summary: None of these Jefferson County neighbors have made a public stance on development or clean energy known. No clear supporters or opponents emerged; all are categorized as unknown stance. Community influence is generally modest – two neighbors have medium influence due to local civic or farming ties, while the others maintain low public profiles.

neighbors.name: Seventh-day Adventist Church (Trustees)
neighbors.claims: This parcel is owned by the Seventh-day Adventist Church in Jefferson County, with the title held by its local trustees [Church Angel](https://www.churchangel.com/directory/listing/seventh-day-adventist-church-124). The church’s property is located on Summit Point Road near Charles Town, WV [Church Angel](https://www.churchangel.com/directory/listing/seventh-day-adventist-church-124).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage through the church leadership. Coordinate outreach with the congregation’s pastor and trustees to address any concerns respectfully.

neighbors.name: Henry B. Davenport III & Faye B. Davenport
neighbors.claims: Henry B. Davenport III comes from a longstanding local family – an earlier Henry B. Davenport (1865–1958) of Jefferson County is documented in historical archives [WVU Libraries](https://wvhistoryonview.org/catalog/037793). Public records show Henry B. Davenport III holds several out-of-state mineral rights interests (e.g., Texas oil/gas royalties) under his name, indicating substantial property assets [MineralHolders](https://www.mineralholders.com/west-virginia/charles-town/henry-b-davenport-iii/4694288).

approach_recommendations.engage: Highlight respect for the Davenport family’s generations in the area. A personal approach acknowledging their long-term legacy can help build trust and open dialogue.

neighbors.name: Douglas B. Lutman & Patricia A. Lutman
neighbors.claims: Douglas B. and Patricia A. Lutman are involved in local agriculture; their family business, Lutman Properties LLC, was established in 2011 with a stated purpose of crop farming in Jefferson County [WV Secretary of State](https://apps.sos.wv.gov/business/corporations/organization.aspx?org=303635). The Lutman family name has appeared in county affairs – for example, a Charles Lutman served on the Jefferson County Planning Commission in the early 1990s [Justia](https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F3/2/48/615844/).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Lutmans via shared agricultural interests. Emphasize how project plans address farmland preservation and invite their input in the planning process to respect local control.

neighbors.name: Brandt G. Turner & Rebekah L. Turner
neighbors.claims: Brandt G. Turner and Rebekah L. Turner have a very limited public footprint in Jefferson County. No references to either in local news reports or civic records could be found as of this review, suggesting they have not held any prominent community roles or spoken publicly on development issues [Jefferson County Commission](https://www.jeffersoncountywv.org/county-government/county-commission/meeting-minutes).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach the Turners privately to learn their concerns. Since they maintain a low profile, a neighborly one-on-one conversation to listen and inform would be the most effective engagement.

neighbors.name: Fonnie R. Crawford & Sylvia M. Crawford
neighbors.claims: Fonnie R. Crawford and Sylvia M. Crawford do not appear in any prominent public records beyond property ownership in Jefferson County. A name search mainly yields unrelated items (such as an appeals case involving a different individual named Crawford), indicating that this couple has not been publicly active in local affairs [FindLaw](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/wv-supreme-court-of-appeals/1586366.html).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Crawfords with a personal, respectful approach. Given their lack of public involvement, it may be best to reach out through a mutual acquaintance or community forum to hear their views quietly.
